AK Notes: AK SNAP BBCE eliminates asset test; uses Alaska-specific poverty guidelines (approximately 25% higher than lower 48)
Asset values not required for AK SNAP under BBCE
Asset verification not required for AK SNAP under BBCE
AK SNAP: not applicable under BBCE. AK Medicaid Non-MAGI: follows federal SSI resource limits ($2,000 individual / $3,000 couple). Alaska is a 1634 state.
AK SNAP: always true under BBCE; no resource test

AK SNAP uses 200% FPL gross income threshold under BBCE. Alaska uses separate, higher Federal Poverty Level guidelines (approximately 25% higher than lower 48 states). All FPL-based thresholds in Alaska use Alaska-specific guidelines.
AK SNAP: 200% FPL gross income test only under BBCE; no net income test. All FPL calculations use Alaska-specific poverty guidelines.
BBCE removes categorical ineligibility for lottery/gambling winnings in AK SNAP
Follows substantialLotteryWinnings removal under BBCE
Alaska has obtained statewide ABAWD waivers due to qualifying unemployment rates and lack of sufficient employment opportunities in rural areas. Most of Alaska qualifies for ABAWD time-limit waivers.

Permanent Fund Dividend (PFD) amount ($1,000-$3,200/year depending on year). PFD counts as unearned income for SNAP and other means-tested programs. This is unique to Alaska. PFD is paid annually in October; must be annualized for monthly income calculations.

Denali KidCare covers lawfully present children and pregnant women. Tribal health integration: Alaska Natives eligible for Indian Health Service regardless of other coverage. APA requires lawful presence.

Alaska Medicaid (MAGI): 138% FPL adults, 200% FPL children via Denali KidCare, 200% FPL pregnant women. All thresholds use Alaska-specific poverty guidelines (approximately 25% higher than lower 48). SSI auto-enrollment (1634 state). Tribal health eligible individuals may receive IHS services independent of Medicaid.

AK is a 1634 state: SSI recipients receive automatic Medicaid enrollment. Tribal health intersection: Alaska Natives enrolled in tribal health may qualify for 100% FMAP services. 229 federally recognized tribes in Alaska.

Indian Health Service / tribal health eligibility. Alaska has 229 federally recognized tribes. Alaska Natives eligible for IHS and tribal health services. Tribal health referrals qualify for 100% FMAP. Critical for Medicaid billing and coordination of benefits.

Medicaid Buy-In for Workers with Disabilities: working disabled individuals eligible for Medicaid with higher income limits. Alaska participates in the Medicaid Buy-In program under the Ticket to Work and Work Incentives Improvement Act.
Must demonstrate current employment for Medicaid Buy-In eligibility

60-month federal lifetime limit applies to ATAP (Alaska Temporary Assistance Program). Strong tribal TANF presence: 229 federally recognized tribes; multiple tribal TANF programs operate independently with separate time limits and work requirements. Tribal TANF months may not count toward state ATAP limit.
ATAP good cause exemption includes domestic violence per Family Violence Option. Alaska Child Support Services Division (CSSD) handles enforcement.

AK Heating Assistance uses 150% FPL (Alaska guidelines) as income threshold. Critical program given extreme heating costs in Alaska; average heating season costs exceed $5,000 in rural areas. Administered by Alaska Housing Finance Corporation (AHFC).

Extreme heating costs in Alaska; fuel oil predominant in rural areas. Many rural communities require barge or air fuel delivery. AHFC administers Heating Assistance. Average annual heating costs in rural Alaska can exceed $8,000. Heat/eat: Heating Assistance benefit confers SNAP Standard Utility Allowance (SUA) eligibility.

Remote fuel delivery indicator. Many rural Alaska communities are off the road system and require barge or air fuel delivery, significantly increasing heating costs. Affects benefit calculation for Heating Assistance. Communities may have only one annual barge delivery window.

Adult Public Assistance (APA) amount. State supplement to SSI for aged (65+), blind, and disabled individuals. APA is state-funded and administered by the Alaska Division of Public Assistance. Benefit amount varies based on living arrangement and other income.
APA: cash assistance for aged (65+), blind, and disabled individuals. State supplement to SSI. Alaska is a 1634 state. Administered by Division of Public Assistance.

AK General Assistance: interim cash assistance for individuals pending SSI determination. State-funded. Administered by Division of Public Assistance. Recipients must apply for and cooperate with SSI application.
Senior Benefits: monthly payment ($250) for low-income Alaskans aged 65 and older. Income threshold based on FPL (Alaska guidelines). State-funded. Administered by Division of Public Assistance.
Required for all state-only programs. APA requires age 65+ (or blind/disabled). Senior Benefits requires age 65+.
Required for all state-only programs
Must meet SSI disability criteria for APA eligibility (aged, blind, or disabled)
Income type required for all state-only programs. PFD counts as income.
Income verification required for all state-only programs

Alaska has no counties. Uses 19 organized boroughs and 10 census areas (29 total). Much of the state is in the Unorganized Borough. Borough code identifies administering office and regional service area. Replaces countyCode used in other state overlays.
ARIES (Alaska Resource for Integrated Eligibility Services) case tracking number. Alaska uses ARIES as the statewide integrated eligibility system for all Division of Public Assistance programs.

Verification of Alaska residency required for all state-administered programs. Alaska residency also required for PFD eligibility (separate from benefits programs). PFD residency requirements are stricter than benefits program residency requirements.
ARIES eligibility system client identifier. Used across all Division of Public Assistance programs.

Added yupik|inupiaq|tlingit|samoan for Alaska Native languages and Pacific Islander communities per Alaska language access requirements. Yup'ik is the most widely spoken Alaska Native language. Inupiaq, Tlingit are official state languages alongside English (AS 44.12.310).

fuel_oil is the predominant heating fuel in rural Alaska. Many communities are off the road system and receive fuel_oil via barge or air delivery. Wood is also significant in rural areas. Natural gas primarily available in Anchorage/Fairbanks metro areas.
